newsitem.title: UK: Biocompatibles up in rebound from lows.
newsitem.headline: Biocompatibles up in rebound from lows.

text.p: Shares in Britain's Biocompatibles Plc shot higher on Friday, recovering from recent weakness as a press report highlighted positive comment on the stock from Merrill Lynch, dealers said.
The shares were up 175p, or 17.9 percent, at 11.55 stg by 1046 GMT. On Thursday the stock fell to a low of 950p, its lowest since January.

The Financial Times noted that Biocompatibles shares had been depressed recently by worries over an apparent delay to talks with Johnson & Johnson, concerning Biocompatibles' "stent" products used to free blocked-up arteries.
However, the paper said Merrill analysts remained positive on the stock.
Nigel Barnes at Merrill told Reuters he believed worries over the Johnson & Johnson talks had been overdone.

Barnes said the talks had been expanded from their initial aim of allowing J&J to license Biocompatibles technology to use in its own products, to include the possibility of the U.S. firm directly marketing Biocompatibles products.
On Wednesday, Biocompatibles said in a statement its talks with J&J were continuing and a further announcement would be made once negotiations had been completed.
Dealers said the report had helped jerk the stock out of its recent slump. "It has just been bombed out in the past few days," said one, adding that he was not aware of any other news in the market.
